Reviews.Title: “Good cost-benefit”
Reviews.Author: Mariusm98
Reviews.Content: For just one night the location -3 minutes walk from the central station- is excellent. In contrast to another reviewer, my room had both wifi and steaming hot water. A bit lean breakfast.

Reviews.Title: “Disappointed in this Hotel!”
Reviews.Author: NYWldTraveler
Reviews.Content: Searched this hotel for stay in Rome before cruise. The rating & reviews were a bit off for this property. Location was really best feature, however, room & lack of hot water (tepid at best) was most disappointing. Room was very quiet & front desk personnel who was reserved & relatively cordial was not forthcoming with suggestions or recommendations. Wifi only worked in lobby area & not in the room. Price was very good, 50 euros, per night but I've stayed in other hotels in Rome last year for same rate which was a better room & facilities.

Reviews.Title: “Basic but good location”
Reviews.Author: Cindy L
Reviews.Content: I booked the hotel after reading the reviews here, so I wasn’t too disappointed when got inside the room 207, and my review is only based on this room. The hotel was not difficult to find if you follow the tram track to Street Cavour after come out of the Termini station, walking about five minutes, the hotel is on your right. The next door is a souvenir shop where you can buy an adopter for your chargers as Italian use a 3 pin plug, it cost €5. The room 207 was very basic as many of others described. The room was tiny but clean. There wasn’t much of the view as the hotel was behind another ugly dirty building. No air-conditioning but a fan in the room, it was end of September so it was ok at night; the pillow was very thin, I had to put my clothes underneath it; the TV was small and it didn’t have a signal, I don’t speak Italian anyway so didn’t bother to ask for a change or repairing. I had to share the bathroom with others who stayed on the same floor, I didn’t mind until the second night when I went in to find out that the bathroom was like an elephant had just been taking a bath in it, water was everywhere on the floor, I guess some people just don’t consider of other users. The toilet was as difficult to use as described by others, so I had to use the free toilet in the museums or galleries for three days, (they charge you €1 for using toilet at the Termini station!) The wall was quite thin, the first night I was exhausted so went to bed early. Around eleven o’clock, I was woken by the couple next door who were chatting in their room loudly, that lady’s laughter was so dramatic! The third night I couldn’t sleep because the noises from the air condition units outside. The breakfast was the worst I have ever had, only a couple of bread rolls and a cup of tea. When checked out, on top of €60/night there was also €2 each night for city tax. I am not sure if I should recommend this hotel as I would not go back myself, for that price I would find a more comfortable place but a little bit outside the centre area next time. If you have not yet bored with my review, that I would like to share a few experiences which may benefit your future trip. 1. When arriving Roma, there is a shuttle bus (at airport stand 1) from the airport to Roma city centre, €8 single way or €15 returns. It runs every hour and seven days a week. It takes approximate an hour to get to the Roma city centre. It has two stops, first stop is Vatican, and then Termini station in the city centre. 2. I booked ‘skip the line’ on the Vatican museum website which cost me €27 + €7 audio tour hiring. However, the ticket price of Vatican museum was only €15, and you have to queue for the security check anyway. Most of these skip the line services are in the morning when most of the tourists have the same idea to visit the museum early, you couldn’t see much without push or been pushed. I stayed until noon when there are less people so I could calmly enjoy my visiting. It’s same to St. Peter’s a long queue in the morning but much less people visiting after 2pm. 3. There are two lines of underground in Roma which can take you to all the attractions. From Termini station to Vatican museum (Ottaviano, San Pietro) only six stops by using Line A and only cost €1 for a single trip, but don’t be surprised if you can’t find many English instructions. 4. There is a small supermarket at lower level of Termini station which is the only one that I could find in the city, the price of the food was reasonable; you can enjoy some fresh fruit and yogurt. 5. The sightseeing tour bus by passes most tourist attractions in the city centre, to find your way around you have to have a detailed street map as the old town have so many small streets and visibility of street signs on some buildings is not good in the dark. 6. If you are a cat lover, please bring some cat treats when visit Vatican museum. There is a black cat - Mr.V that just looks like my cat Maomao. He is a very nice and sociable cat, when I chilled out in the garden, he walked toward me and sit down next to my feet enjoyed me patting him. He’s quite slim which makes his head looks much bigger. Poor creature even fought over a couple of piece bread with pigeons!

Reviews.Title: “Works for the Price”
Reviews.Author: SCagray
Reviews.Content: This hotel was exactly what I was looking for at the end of my trip. A place to stay that was clean, affordable, and close to the train station. I just needed to crash and get up early for a flight out. This worked so well. I walked to and from the station (only works if you have minimal luggage) and saved on cab fare. A good thing since I had just spent three weeks throughout Italy and was low on funds. There are plenty of great places to eat in the area and a nice place to say goodbye to Rome.

Reviews.Title: “Good base for a city break”
Reviews.Author: Kathryn M
Reviews.Content: Great location, VERY near ROMA Centrale. Air con was an added bonus to an economy hotel. Breakfast was adequate but clean and a good base for a city break.

Reviews.Title: “Nice Hotel Good Location”
Reviews.Author: djsolomb
Reviews.Content: Our hotel room was very large and the air conditioning worked very well. The hotel is 3 or 4 blocks from the train station and a short walk to the Colosseum. The room is very simple, clean and spacious! Breakfast was rolls and coffee. We would stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “Avoid This Place”
Reviews.Author: Soggiorno
Reviews.Content: This hotel is one of several that share some big, old buildings along the Via Cavour. We were a group of four and were placed in two rooms. The rooms were tiny. Neither had functioning air conditioning, though it was the middle of a Rome summer. Ours "sort of" worked, but our friends' room had no A/C at all. The staff moved them to another room and that didn't work, either. Although we didn't have A/C, we DID have a TV that didn't work... The only good thing I can say about this place is that it's very convenient to the main train station, Roma Termini, which made it that much easier when we beat a hasty and early retreat. The people in the office were nice enough, if ineffectual. It was cheap for what you didn't get, though.

Reviews.Title: “Cheap, clean base for Rome touring”
Reviews.Author: MrsKruse
Reviews.Content: We spent one night at the Hotel Cavour before catching a cruise boat for 12 days. As we were already horribly over budget from the day we began planning, I was looking for anything that didn't appear to have rodents, was within a few blocks of major sites or the metro, and under $150/night. That's actually pretty hard in Rome, I found. Enter the Hotel Cavour. For 75 euros a night (about $110 a night), we got exactly what we paid for. A very clean (but cramped) double room with a sink and bidet, shower & toilet shared for the hall (though we never saw anyone else using it). Bed a bit stiff, but hey, you can only expect so much for 75 euros. Two blocks from Termini, so easy to catch a bus or train to anywhere you please. And, if you have your walking shoes on, you can be at the Colosseum within 20 minutes or so. The staff was friendly and provided a nice walking map (though we found our GPS on our phone to be more useful). Everyone spoke good English. They have a lift, though you will need to drag your bag up a stair or two to get into the office. They also have an included breakfast (though we chose to sleep in to work off the jet lag) and free wifi in the lobby (handy for a last blast of email before hitting the sea). TV is only in Italian, but we didn't come to Italy to watch TV (and watching TV in a language that you speak very little of is actually a lot of fun). This isn't a place for luxury, but for those wanting to save some pennies while seeing Rome, it's an excellent value. Speaking to others on our trip, we found that many paid double what we did to stay in Rome and had much worse rooms & service!

Reviews.Title: “Awesome location on a tight budget.”
Reviews.Author: rhirhi11
Reviews.Content: Was on a very tight budget, and this place fit it. It was secure and safe. Service was awesome- housekeeping and reception were really great. The rooms weren't anything flash, but they were clean. Internet was reliable. And the location was awesome. 5 minutes from Termini, and right on Via Cavour. Awesome.

Reviews.Title: “great location but yuck!”
Reviews.Author: BellaMurphy86
Reviews.Content: The location of this hotel was absolutely fantastic and staff was very helpful but it was a bit of a dump. We had a double room but it was dirty, tired and very very basic. The shared bathroom was a joke. The shower was so close to the toilet that you could not sit on it properly. The shower was also constantly blocked and you would end up in a pool of water up to almost your ankles. I guess you get what you pay for.

Reviews.Title: “Location and Price”
Reviews.Author: jojotn
Reviews.Content: We spent two days in Rome prior to going on a cruise with our 4 children and mother. We were booked at another hotel close by, but when we arrived (after arriving in Rome at 8AM and going on an all-day tour--i.e. exhausted), we were informed that we had been bumped from our rooms due to some guests who decided to not leave the day they were supposed to leave. To the credit of this hotel, they booked us into the Hotel Cavour. It was perfectly adequate, probably nicer than our original hotel, and a great location. The proximity to the Termini Station is definitely a plus. The room was spacious, especially for Europe. My only problem was figuring out that the key card had to be used to turn the lights on! :-) The staff was helpful and friendly. The included breakfast was quite good. It was a good value for the price. About 200 euro per night per room. We would definitely stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “Near the station, clean, good service”
Reviews.Author: LauskiLondon
Reviews.Content: Staff awere very helpful, the hotel is nothing special but does the job for a group of backpacking girls. The room was nice and clean and the location was perfect - just 3 minutes walk from the station and about 10 max to sites such as the coliseum. The trvisio fountain was a bit further - about 45 min walk but easily accesible on bus.

Reviews.Title: “Great Service for a Great Vacation Area”
Reviews.Author: jcantr9610
Reviews.Content: This hotel offered excellent service, with english speaking front desk personnel. Italy is a great vacation, with lots of history and sites to see. Very good value hotel. Would stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “No problems, great value and location”
Reviews.Author: Old_Gregg_9
Reviews.Content: Wi-fi is free and reliable. Staff were very friendly. 11am checkout. Room is as nice or nicer than Hotel Julia, and pretty much the same thing but without the noise and 40e cheaper. Only stayed 1 night but should have stayed all 4! Probably depends on which room you get though, as I can see how some of them would be noisy, as the front of the building is on Via Cavour. But my room was at the back and fine. Location is awesome, close to Roma Termini and Colosseum etc. Double bed room was 65e (single use). Breakfast was a bit lacking, but not complaining for the price.

Reviews.Title: “Avoid Hotel Cavour”
Reviews.Author: ULTRANERDX
Reviews.Content: We did not enjoy our stay at Hotel Cavour and we found the area surrounding Termini station to be an undesirable and inconvenient place to stay in Rome. Even if you’re used to walking all the time, it is still a good 30+ minute walk to the nearest sites. A better area would be around the Spagna subway station. Aside from the location, the hotel was just not very nice. The hallways smelled terrible and the room didn’t smell very good either and was very hot (in early March). And when we tried to open our window to let the smell/heat out, the stench from the Chinese restaurant in the alley wafted in—so you had to make a calculated decision regarding which smell was worse. There was seemingly zero ventilation in the bathroom, which was probably no larger than a 10-foot closet. The lighting was bad, the walls were painted an odd yellow-y color that made it feel dirty, and the air conditioner/fan did not work. Breakfast was bread and off-brand Nutella and juice. I believe we paid ~$88/night for the room, and it was not worth it—I’m not even sure that we would have stayed there for $50/night.

Reviews.Title: “ZekiCypriot”
Reviews.Author: ZekiCypriot
Reviews.Content: I stayed 7 nights in a single room at Hotel Cavour. The location of the Hotel is excellent. It is only 150-200 m. to Rome's main railway, metro and bus station Termini and a few blocs away from the Cavour Station. Transportation within Rome and to other cities of Italy is not a big problem. A bus-stop just in front of the building entance and many taxis around. Plenty of restaurants, cafes, pharmacies, souvenir shops and boutiques available in the near vicinity. In general the area was safe even at night. The room was small but very functional. If you like to stay in a hotel and spend the day and night there, this is not the right address. But if you prefer to use the hotel as a fresh starting point to the day with a breakfast and for having a shower and a good sleep after a backbreaking day, that is. Of course the breakfast is an "Italian breakfast"... coffee, croissant, a slice of bread and jam. The room was CLEAN. The bath towels changed everyday and were so white looked like new. A small shower but a high water pressure making you a relaxing massage. A working air condition included in the price ( which is not usual in most Roma hotels. They charge you extra.) Although the hotel is situated on a busy road there were no disturbing noise in my room. An excellent team in the reception. All were very polite and helpful. Alfredo, Lorenzo, Andy and Elisa replied my endless questions with patience. If you compare the price you pay and the services you get it is absolutely a value for money hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Check for your A/C”
Reviews.Author: LAMarathonMom
Reviews.Content: My daughters and I stayed at the Hotel Cavour the first week of August, when it was incredibly hot. One of our rooms was air conditioned, the other was not (despite the hotel being listed as air-conditioned on their web site). So we moved mattresses from one room to another so we could all sleep comfortably. The hotel was a very convenient base to all we wanted to see and do in Rome and the access to the train and Metro couldn't be better. The rooms (and baths) were clean, but the mattresses were too firm. With the caveat that you should check the status of air conditioning in YOUR room prior to arrival, I'd recommend this hotel for the budget traveler.

Reviews.Title: “Great location, clean hotel, friendly staff”
Reviews.Author: tsbert
Reviews.Content: We booked the Hotel Cavour through Venere.com. We were supposed to stay two nights but due to flight trouble on our side, we weren't able to make it for the first night. We contacted the hotel in the middle of the night before we were originally due to arrive. They were great - even though we cancelled about 12 hours before we were due to arrive, they did not charge us for the night we weren't there. We arrived a day late, but we were happy with the hotel. We paid 130 euro for a room with a double bed and private bathroom. The room was small but clean. The air conditioning worked well, the window shutters blocked out all light (which is great when you've been awake for 30 hours and need to sleep), the water pressure in the shower was good. The location of the hotel was fabulous. It was about 2 blocks from the Terminal Station. We were able to use both the Metro and buses with no problem. The area seemed safe to us. The only issue was with the lack of safes or safety deposit boxes. There weren't in room safes so we left our money at the front desk. When we came back in the evening, the money had been locked in the manager's office and no one could get it. We didn't worry too much, but it was a hassle since our cell phone was with the money and we wanted to call home. However, the manager was in early enough in the morning and we were able to go on our way happily. We'd stay at the hotel again.

Reviews.Title: “Great Staff Average Hotel”
Reviews.Author: Appleetty
Reviews.Content: Rome is super expensive especially if you want a private room. Keeping this in mind I thought Hotel Cavour was a good deal. We paid 80 euro per night, which included breakfast but we shared bathroom facilities. Massimo is awesome and lifts the hotel from average to above average. Definitely ask him for advise on where to eat etc but don't bother with the other guy we found him to be a bit rude and condescending. The room itself was average, but the bed was comfortable, it was quiet and the air conditioning in our room was really good. All in all I think you need a bit of luxury in Rome, it's hot and hard going but if you can't afford it definitely check out Hotel Cavour, you could do a lot worse.

Reviews.Title: “Small room, A/C was poor”
Reviews.Author: Devon_Anglophile
Reviews.Content: I spent one night at this place on May 15th. The lobby and breakfast room were small but wonderfully air conditioned. Too bad my room air conditioner was not up to the same quality as the lobby. Because of the poor AC I did not get a good night’s sleep – but I did on my flight the next day. The room was clean and I did have a private bathroom, although it was small, as expected.

Reviews.Title: “Average at the most”
Reviews.Author: Mtlsouth
Reviews.Content: Quick overview: Just spent 22 days (April 9-30) in Italy as a single traveler: I stayed in 12 hotels priced from 50 to 80 Eur/night. I looked long and hard on the Internet to find the best hotels I could afford. In general, most of them are better than “budget/backpacker” hotels and you get great value for your buck: I rated 3 “average”, 5 “good” and 4 “outstanding”. Here is a quick review of this hotel as compared with the others. My last hotel in Italy, in Rome, was a disappointment. I booked at Hotel Cavour a bit late and it was not my first choice but everything else was already booked: I ended up with a very small room without bathroom (although I had a sink and bidet in my room, the shower and toilet were shared). My room, #514, was about 6X12 sq. feet and was NOT the smallest room on the 5th floor! According to the floor plan room #532 was even smaller and was located right beside one of the shared bathroom where the fan was very noisy!!! 2 bathrooms were shared by 5 rooms. Everything looked old and worn out. The building, shared by other hotels, is about 5min. from the Termini station and 15min. to the coliseum. Reception is on the 1st floor and so is the breakfast room: breakfast is less than stellar with 1 croissant/bread, jam and a coffee. I truly hope that the other rooms are better but at 70 Eur/night, this hotel was not a good deal, not too bad but AVERAGE at the most.

Reviews.Title: “Great Staff Great Location”
Reviews.Author: dankmartini
Reviews.Content: Hotel Cavour emailed to confirm my reservation and when I arrived greeted me heartily by name. The staff speak excellent English and were extremely helpful in helping me find a place to eat dinner. Breakfast was simple Italian style but adequate. Location is excellent. A 10 minute walk to the Collesium and Forum and about a 20 minute walk to the Pantheon and Fontana de Trevi. It is a bit difficult to find, so google for a picture of the outside of the hotel. The rooms were simple and clean and above all very quiet. Note that all of the rooms are on the top floors so you will have to climb the stairs or use the small lift to get to you room. Overall a good value and a good location.

Reviews.Title: “Good value”
Reviews.Author: Solo2007
Reviews.Content: I stayed in this hotel for three nights while visiting Italy last March, and would definitely come back. I had a single room with shared bathroom. Since there only three rooms sharing it, I didn't have to wait most of the time. My room was quite because it didn't face the street. Room is simple but clean. The receptionist was very helpful. I borrowed a haridryer from him. Breakfast was basic but good for the money. Since I only paid 40 euros per night. Locatin is excellent, 3 minutes walk to the train station. A good value hotel!

Reviews.Title: “Recommended”
Reviews.Author: doicher
Reviews.Content: It has to be admitted that the area around Hotel Cavour is run-down, dirty and littered, with Graffiti on every building and most other objects too. The traffic is appalling, the noise and fumes are unbelieveable, and you take your life in your hands every time you cross the street. Street urchins will steal everything you give them the chance to, and everywhere are beggars, scroungers and layabouts of every sort. However ..... you will find that almost all areas of central Rome are as bad, or even worse! As for Hotel Cavour, for the price it is excellent. Entering the building housing Hotel Cavour (which it shares with two other hotels and a Pensione), is not too encouraging. However, you will find the Hotel Cavour rooms are perfectly OK, with modern and clean en-suite facilities. The beds are a bit hard, but that is good for you, isn’t it? The people in reception are super, and cannot be more helpful. The location is perfect from the perspective of getting around. From the hotel to the Metro is no more than 200 metres, and to the main Termini Station is about 300 metres. The Termini itself contains shops etc and ATM machines. Some say Hotel Cavour is hard to find - nonsense, just remember it is number 47 Via Cavour. Look at your online maps like Multimap. At the top of Via Cavour stand with your back to the Termini (Piazza Cinquecento) looking down Via Cavour. Hotel Cavour is on the right hand side – the most prominent sign being Hotel Argentina in the same building! The location is about half-way between Via Antonio Rosmini and Via Principe Amedeo. This area is choc-a-bloc with excellent small restaurants, and you cannot go too far wrong with most of them. However, the Restaurant Santi in Via Daniele Manin is well worth a mention since here you have a genuine family-run restaurant offering Roman (and other provinces) food. Yes, they have the Menu Turisitico if you want to ease yourself in gently – but then go for the local stuff! Signori and Signora Santi are in their seventies and have been running this restaurant for most of their married lives – try it! Finally – if you want to do Rome, you’ll be hard put to find a better compromise than this area.

Reviews.Title: “A pleasnt experience”
Reviews.Author: wherleybird
Reviews.Content: A great find in a crowded city. 47 Cavour is very close to the Termini and an easy walk to all of Rome's major attractions. It is very close to the Coliseum and about a 45 minute stroll through the city to reach the Vatican. i would recomend this hotel to anyone. The rooms are very small but very clean. For the price, you won't do much better in expensive Rome. The staff at the front is extremely polite and very helpful. This is a traditional tourist hotel that will give you a good nights rest. If you are a 'hotel' person who likes ammentities, go elsewhere, but if you want a clean, safe, friendly place to lay your head after a long day of sighseeing, I would say this would suit you well. Happy travels.

Reviews.Title: “Nice, good location”
Reviews.Author: hunter0008
Reviews.Content: Let me first start off by saying that if you are traveling in the summer, get a room with A/C...especially if you are from the U.S. and used to the A/C. Let me then warn you that the A/C's in Europe have about the same power as a Geo Metro. Let me then say again that this hotel was the ONLY hotel in Europe that we stayed at that finally got the idea that all you really need is a ceiling fan!! This hotel had a ceiling fan AND an A/C unit. Rome is extremely brutal and hot and to come home to a cold room is excellent. The hotel is actually on the 5th floor I believe, but there is a lift, so it isn't very inconvenient to get to the room at all. The shared bathrooms that we had were ok and the rooms were pretty clean. The proximatey to the train station was excellent. Right down the block. Not a bad walk at all to all the locations of Rome besides the Vatican. For the price, I would definitely recommend this hotel. The staff was very nice as well.

Reviews.Title: “Close to Termini”
Reviews.Author: bargaintraveller
Reviews.Content: With a few minor changes this hotel could be a perfect base in Rome. We arrived close to midnight, hours late after a delayed flight from Venice, the young man on reception was excellent, as were all the staff throughout our stay. It is typical of hotels we have stay in when we have visited Rome, our recpt on the ground floor and rooms on 2nd & 5th with other hotels on the floors between. One old small lift to all floors was only a problem on two occassions. We had an ensuite room that had a 7inch drop as soon as you entered the room. Not a problem once you knew it was there, but on arrival I fell into the room as there was no warning of it on the door. If you like a good nights sleep be sure to request a room that does not face via Cavour as the noise from the traffic is 24/7 and with no double glazing you hear it constantly. Italians use their car horns to drive as well. The breakfast staff were super but their fair a little basic, although to their credit its one of the few places I have stayed and had hot coffee, much better than the warm variety. For a 2* hotel at a reasonable price for the centre of Rome you could do alot worse than stay here.
